linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 1 shows a satellite image of the Golfo San Jorge basin with its location in Argentina and the location of exploitation and exploration concessions.
A sucint description of reservoir characteristics and operation data of Golfo San Jorge basin (Figure 2) shows that:

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Schematic Example of Three-Dimensional Reservoir Distribution

formatted-caption.caption-text: Schematic Example of Three-Dimensional Reservoir Distribution

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 3 shows fields where the WF started, beginning with Cañadón León and Anticlinal Grande and other fields of Cerro Dragón along with Pico Truncado (El destino). In the 1980s, several WF processes started in Chubut and Santa Cruz provinces, and in the 1990s the projects of the rest of the major concessions began. Between 1993 and 1999, WF processes were intensively developed in the largest companies. Even so the intensity of these developments has been very heterogeneous and clearly partial as can be seen in further sections. Qualitatively it can be said that the secondary or WF development it is between advanced and partially advanced depending on its location.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Golfo San Jorge (GSJ) Basin Fields and Simplified History of Wateflooding Developments

formatted-caption.caption-text: Golfo San Jorge (GSJ) Basin Fields and Simplified History of Wateflooding Developments

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 4 shows the reconstruction of the production history on a logarithmic scale, based on three different public databases of the Ministry of Energy.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Golfo San Jorge Basin Production and Wells History

formatted-caption.caption-text: Golfo San Jorge Basin Production and Wells History

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 5 shows the wells status according to the different colors: (i) in green: active oil producers, (ii) in blue: injectors, (iii) in red: gas producers, (iv) in black: Abandoned or to be abandoned and (v) in gray: shut in wells for any reason. As mentioned before, there are 11,500 shut in wells, suggesting that there is room for improvement, partly through their usage previous mechanical status check) as producers and/or water injectors. In fact, many of them are supposedly being considered as part of the future development plans in the Reserves and Resources Plans informed.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Golfo San Jorge Basin Well Satus – December 2015

formatted-caption.caption-text: Golfo San Jorge Basin Well Satus – December 2015

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Figure 6 shows only active injector wells, it is possible to have a visual appreciation of the degree of the waterflooding development and to understand its intensity, when comparing Figure 5 with Figure 6. The more intensely blue (a few ones) zones are those that have more injectors and more confinement of producers with well spacings from 300 m to some cases of 170 m. The latter have generally been designed as they have vertically significant reservoir stacking.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Golfo San Jorge Basin Active Injector Wells – December 2015

formatted-caption.caption-text: Golfo San Jorge Basin Active Injector Wells – December 2015

linkTarget.anchoringText: In the absence of the above mentioned information (OOIP and Optimal RF on a reservoir basis) we tried to get closer to knowing the maturity of the fields by including an analysis of the exploitation type that each field has (Primary, Secondary, and Tertiary). Figure 7 shows an approach to the field's maturity degree characterizing each one by its exploitation type and Depletion Factor vs WOR, where different behaviors are observed.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Depletion Factor vs WOR per Field – March 2016 - GSJ Basin

formatted-caption.caption-text: Depletion Factor vs WOR per Field – March 2016 - GSJ Basin

linkTarget.anchoringText: The more than 15 years experience of multidisciplinary teams (typically conformed by both VYP Consultores SA staff and the Client's professionals) using a consistent and detailed methodology and having an important areal coverage of the basin, allows us to make many observations and estimate intrinsic parameters needed to screen and evaluate incremental projects. Figure 8 shows the block studies carried out which represent 13% of the total wells in the basin and 25% of the current water injection volume.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Studied Blocks in Golfo San Jorge Basin

formatted-caption.caption-text: Studied Blocks in Golfo San Jorge Basin

linkTarget.anchoringText: This important amount of studies allowed the knowledge of: general characteristics, efficiencies, recovery factors by type, Waterflooding contacted (and contactable) fractions and a better understanding of the problems (and opportunities) (Figure 9) of each block associated with:

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Problems Associated with Reservoirs and Design, Implementation, Monitoring, and Follow-up of WF Processes

formatted-caption.caption-text: Problems Associated with Reservoirs and Design, Implementation, Monitoring, and Follow-up of WF Processes

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 10 shows the estimated OOIP (bubble size) with the 3P oil reserves (left axis) and by field type (color coded). In addition, it is included a pie chart with the proportions of OOIP by type of field.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Estimated OOIP vs 3P Oil Reserves by Type – Golfo San Jorge Basin

formatted-caption.caption-text: Estimated OOIP vs 3P Oil Reserves by Type – Golfo San Jorge Basin
